title: Reproducible geographical information Systems and Science
text:
Who am i

Lecturer in Spatial Data Science and Visualization at CASA, UCL
Human Geographer
Run our main MSc programme
Lead MSc modules in:

Geographic information systems and science
Remotely sensing cities and environments

title: Reproducible geographical information Systems and Science
text:
Agendas
Teaching

Empower students to become leading activists in urban spatial science
Equip students with spatial skills for the interpretation of urban data leading to data-informed decisions
Instill critical thought based on a solid theoretical and technical foundation to see through buzz words and hype that are often associated with smart cities / urban analytics.

title: Reproducible geographical information Systems and Science
text:
Research

To have meaningful real world impact on the sustainability of our cities
Operatialising emerging geo-spatial tools for decision making
Place the needs and constraints of decision makers at the heart of all work

title: Reproducible geographical information Systems and Science
text:
A shifting landscape


Paper: Opening practice: supporting reproducibility and critical spatial data science

A comparison of Geographical Weighted regression across:

4 open software packages
2 black box / commercial implementations





All of the implementations were tested with the same input data. They all gave the same results except the ESRI/ArcGIS implementation (Li¬†2018), and although ESRI provide help for the GWR tools, the actual coding is closed‚Äîthe underlying code is not revealed


Source: Brunsdon and Comber, 2021

title: Reproducible geographical information Systems and Science
section: Who has manipulated our boundary data?
text:
Who has manipulated our boundary data?
Redlining



1930s ‚Äì American Home Owner‚Äôs Loan Corporation ‚Äì prevent missed payments‚Ä¶residential security maps based on race

People abandon redlined areas
Can‚Äôt refinance
Less property tax for services






Los Angeles Redlining

title: Reproducible geographical information Systems and Science
section: Who has manipulated our boundary data?
text:
Who has manipulated our boundary data?
Gerrymandering


Every 10 years electoral districts are re-drawn ‚Äúredistricting‚Äù‚Äì Thomas Hofeller (republican) = PACK and CRACK

PACK = put all the democrat voters in 1 district
CRACK = sprinkle them out so they never have majority

title: Reproducible geographical information Systems and Science
text:
1. Lead by example
Problems:


Static
Require updates with software / data




Material is in a pdf
Not easily searchable, limits it to a one time use




A lot of time invested
Only used by students on the module




alumni, academia and industry value programmatic and importantly reproducible GIS analysis

title: Reproducible geographical information Systems and Science
text: Design and outputs

title: Reproducible geographical information Systems and Science
text:
Design and outputs

Course divided into two parts:

Part 1: GIS tools
Part 2: GIS analysis


In part 2 we shift from subject based to problem based learning‚Ä¶.
Each practical answers a question‚Ä¶.


What are the factors that might lead to variation in Average GCSE point scores across the city?

title: Reproducible geographical information Systems and Science
text:
Design and outputs

It is not enough to simply give students some material and hope they will immediately learn it. Learning happens by doing



Weekly homework that we dedicate time to discussing

Week 1-5 tasks
Week 6-9 practice exam

title: Reproducible geographical information Systems and Science
text:
Design and output
Part 1: GIS tools‚Ä¶

You need calculate the average percent of science students (in all) grades per county meeting the required standards and produce a map to show where the Country averages are above or below the State of Washington average.

title: Reproducible geographical information Systems and Science
text:
Practice exam (weeks 5-10), 10%
Final exam (6 hour open book), 90%

title: Reproducible geographical information Systems and Science
section: 2. Make it mandatory for the assessment
text:
2. Make it mandatory for the assessment
Previous iterations

Your task is to carry out a mini research project which answers a pertinent or topical geo-spatial question








Note


Students struggled to come up with a question, source data and apply it

Plagiarism
Poor applications
Very unbalanced reports

End of exam

Run the student‚Äôs code locally
See how often the student edited the code

Marks have improved
All students learn to use reproducibility tools
The tool is not directly assessed
Global use and interaction with the resource

title: Pedagogic challenges 2: urban systems science
section: 2. Make it mandatory for the assessment
text:
2. Make it mandatory for the assessment
DISCUSS

How were the evictions recorded
Why were there limited evictions during 2020/ then a sudden peak? - COVID ban on evictions
How can identifying spatially related factors to evictions be useful
Are there certain areas that have higher evictions than others - why might this be?
What assumption does the data make
What assumptions does the model make

title: Pedagogic challenges 2: urban systems science
text:
Conclusion

It is essential to use data to inform decisions‚Ä¶BUT we must develop a critical awareness of:

How the data has been created
How the boundary data has been created
What the agenda was for collecting the data

In addition we must recognize that:

Data is a snapshot / sample of the population
Analysis attempts to model the world - it is never perfect.



Scientists must have a say in the future of cities, McPhearson 2016




Pedagogic challenges 2: urban systems science ‚Ä¢ Andy MacLachlan

title: Pedagogic challenges 2: urban systems science
text:
What are Urban systems

A set of towns and cities that can be considered linked together by various forms of social and economic interaction

title: Pedagogic challenges 2: urban systems science
text: Urban systems

title: Pedagogic challenges 2: urban systems science
text:
Urban science

Urban science is an interdisciplinary field that studies diverse urban issues and problems

title: Pedagogic challenges 2: urban systems science
text:
What do we mean

Urban systems

A set of towns and cities [or functions within cities] that can be considered linked together by various forms of social and economic interaction


Source: Oxford reference

Systems thinking

Methods aimed at studying a system through its collective behavioral features


Source: Cristiano et al.¬†2020

title: Pedagogic challenges 2: urban systems science
text: Urban systems science

title: Pedagogic challenges 2: urban systems science
text:
Science of cities

The science of cities ‚Äì using evidence to understand how cities work ‚Äì is forever expanding

title: Pedagogic challenges 2: urban systems science
text:
Smart cities

United Nations Thematic Areas

Inclusive cities - equal access to services, increase safety
Sustainable cities - limited resources in most efficient manner
Adaptable cities - mitigate and adapt, air pollution, climate change


Source: Smart Cities

title: Pedagogic challenges 2: urban systems science
text: Ok, what about geographic data

title: Pedagogic challenges 2: urban systems science
text:
What is spatial data?



The earth is a 3D sphere (well, almost). It‚Äôs wider than it is tall
In order to locate a point on the surface of a sphere, we need a set of coordinates
Coordinates will tell us how near to the top or bottom of the sphere we are, or how far around
But where do we start?

title: Pedagogic challenges 2: urban systems science
text:
What is spatial data 2?


Geographic Coordinate Reference System

treats the globe as if it was a sphere divided into 360 equal parts called degrees


Projected Coordinate Reference System

flat, two-dimensional plane (through projecting a spheroid onto a 2D surface) giving it constant lengths, angles and areas










Coordiante reference systems

title: Pedagogic challenges 2: urban systems science
text:
Simply

Spatial data is just like normal data except it has an extra ‚Äúgeometry column‚Äù

title: Pedagogic challenges 2: urban systems science
text:
Big data

Big geospatial data include datasets that are too large to be processed using traditional GIS tools


Source: GIS Harvard

title: Pedagogic challenges 2: urban systems science
text:
What can we d
DuckDB
PostGIS
Earth Engine
CARTO

title: Pedagogic challenges 2: urban systems science
section: What can we do about it?
text:
What can we do about it?
Parquet files

We are moving from row based storage to column based
About 50x faster than a .csv
It groups our data.

For example a row group size of 2, puts rows all the data from 1 and 2 next to each other then we have 3! = GROUPS or PARTITION
If we have large data this means we can skip groups we don‚Äôt need

title: Pedagogic challenges 2: urban systems science
text:
Concepts

You may come across Arrow - this is an in-memory format, Parquet is a storage format

¬†

In the R for Data Science book a 9BG .csv is queried in

11 seconds for standard code
0.063 seconds using a parquet file! 100x faster

title: Pedagogic challenges 2: urban systems science
text: We can go faster!

title: Pedagogic challenges 2: urban systems science
text: Pedagogic challenges 2: urban systems science ‚Ä¢ Andy MacLachlan

title: Pedagogic challenges 2: urban systems science
text:
DuckDB

Database management system
Columnar data
No installation
Convert our Parquet file to DuckDB and back again!


to_duckdb() 
to_arrow()


Regarding performance, parquet is 717 times faster than the same query on a csv file, and duckdb is 2808 times faster.


Source: Christophe Nicault

title: Pedagogic challenges 2: urban systems science
text:
Problems

Currently the support for spatial data is very limited limited
sfarrow - can load and query the data but can‚Äôt do any analysis!

title: Pedagogic challenges 2: urban systems science
section: Who has made our boundary data?
text:
Who has made our boundary data?
Redlining



1930s ‚Äì American Home Owner‚Äôs Loan Corporation ‚Äì prevent missed payments‚Ä¶residential security maps based on race

People abandon areas
Can‚Äôt refinance
Less property tax for services
Social equity issues remain
Illegal since 1968 Fair Housing Act






Los Angeles Redlining

title: Pedagogic challenges 2: urban systems science
section: Who has made our boundary data?
text:
Who has made our boundary data?
Gerrymandering


Every 10 years electoral districts are re-drawn ‚Äúredistricting‚Äù‚Äì Thomas Hofeller (republican) = PACK and CRACK

PACK = put all the democrat voters in 1 district
CRACK = sprinkle them out so they never have majority





Gerrymandering

title: Pedagogic challenges 2: urban systems science
text:
Why are they large?
Raster

Landsat satellite data: 400 scenes of Earth a day, revising each location every 16 days

Each scene is about 1GB
We‚Äôd used Google Earth Engine - not considered here


Vector

New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission (TLC) all records from Yellow and Green Cabs

150GB, 1.2 billion records

Open Street Map

1764.5GB when uncompressed

text:
Notes

All (parquet and DuckDB) make sure of dplyr ! select(), filter(), groupby() = direct integration with R
Currently the support for spatial data is very limited
sfarrow - can load and query the data but can‚Äôt do any analysis!
